questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient from a rural area presents with complaints of itching, irritation, and redness in her eyes for the past few weeks. On examination, multiple follicles are seen on the upper tarsal conjunctiva of both eyes. The patient reports frequent exposure to dust and flies. The ophthalmologist suspects trachoma and starts treatment accordingly. However, the patient shows deterioration after a week of the visit. On further investigation, the ophthalmologist comes to know that the patient has been using a traditional eye medication obtained from a local healer and has not used an adequate dose of antibiotics. What is the most likely cause of the lack of response and deterioration in this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Lack of compliance with the prescribed treatment

questions.correct_answer: C. Use of traditional eye medication

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of uncontrolled hypertension presents with complaints of decreased vision in the right eye for the past 3 months. On examination, visual acuity in the right eye is 6/60, and in the left eye, it is 6/6. There is a right relative afferent pupillary defect. Fundus examination reveals optic disc pallor in the right eye with a cup-to-disc ratio of 0.8:1. MRI of the brain with contrast shows a lesion in the left parietal lobe. What is the most likely diagnosis of this patient's visual pathway abnormality?

A 25-year-old male presents with bilateral redness, irritation, and discharge from his eyes for the past 5 days. On examination, the conjunctiva is congested, and there is a watery discharge. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
Bacterial Viral  Allergic
Clinical signs      
Congestion  Marked      Moderate     Mild to moderate
Subconjunctival hemorrhages May or may not present May or may not present Absent
Chemosis Marked May or may not present Marked
Treatment Topical antibiotic 
  • Cold compression
  • Lubricant eye drops.
  • Topical antibiotic to prevent superinfection
  • Antihistaminic
  • Lubricant eye drops.
  • Cold compression

questions.text: A 2-month-old male infant presents to the pediatric ophthalmology clinic complaining of tearing, photophobia, and a cloudy cornea in the right eye. On examination, the ophthalmologist notes an enlarged cornea with increased intraocular pressure (IOP) in the right eye. Gonioscopy reveals an absence of the trabecular meshwork. The left eye appears normal. Which is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the appropriate treatment for this condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Primary angle-closure glaucoma; laser peripheral iridotomy

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents with recurrent episodes of joint pain and swelling in his left ankle and left knee. He reports that the pain is severe and is associated with stiffness and difficulty in walking. On physical examination, the affected joints are erythematous, warm to touch, and tender on palpation. Laboratory tests reveal elevated serum uric acid levels. X-ray of the affected joints shows erosions and sclerosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient's condition?

options.label: D
options.text: Perform a synovial fluid aspiration and analysis

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presents to the emergency department with a history of bilateral upper and lower limb weakness for the past two hours. She has a long-standing history of rheumatoid arthritis. She is non-compliant with her medications. On examination, power is 2/5 in all the limbs. Babinski’s sign is upgoing bilaterally. The doctor is concerned about atlantoaxial joint instability. Which of the following is the most likely method to evaluate this patient’s atlantoaxial joint?

options.label: A
options.text: Spine lateral view flexion and extension views

questions.correct_answer: A. Spine lateral view flexion and extension views
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Option D: Spine Broden’s view
  • ↳ Option D: Spine Broden’s view
  • ↳ Broden’s view is for the subtalar joint. For the atlantoaxial joint Lateral spine view in extension and flexion position is preferred.
  • ↳ Broden’s view is for the subtalar joint.
  • ↳ For the atlantoaxial joint Lateral spine view in extension and flexion position is preferred.

questions.text: A 16-year-old male presented with progressive pain and swelling in his left knee for the past 3 months. Physical examination revealed a firm, tender, and mildly swollen mass in the distal femur. X-ray showed: MRI revealed a lesion with heterogeneous signal intensity in the distal femur, extending into the epiphysis and metaphysis. Which of the following is less likely a common site for metastasis in this case?

A 62-year-old male has complained of progressive lower back pain and difficulty walking for six months. He also reports hearing loss and has noticed increased shoe size. On examination, he has a stooped posture, an antalgic gait, and tenderness over the lumbar spine. His neurological examination is unremarkable. Further investigations reveal elevated serum alkaline phosphatase, normal serum calcium and phosphate levels, and increased urinary hydroxyproline levels. Which of the following is /are characteristic feature(s) of the diagnosis in this patient?

A 48-year-old man was hospitalized with a severe respiratory infection and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). A bacterial infection was suspected. In order to confirm it, the sample was studied under an electron microscope. While using the electron microscope, two chemicals, namely, glutaraldehyde and lead citrate, are used. In which of the following steps are these chemicals used respectively?

A 10-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a fever, sore throat, and difficulty swallowing. On examination, the patient is found to have erythema and exudate on the tonsils. A throat swab is taken and sent for microbiological culture. The culture reveals the presence of Haemophilus influenzae. Which of the following virulence factors of H. influenzae is responsible for the patient's symptoms?

A patient is diagnosed with a severe bacterial infection. Hospital laboratory tests reveal that the bacteria causing the infection possess antibiotic-resistance genes. Upon further investigation, it was discovered that the patient recently underwent a dental procedure during which the dentist used a contaminated instrument. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely responsible for transferring antibiotic resistance genes between bacteria in this case?
questions.explanation:
Characteristics

Processes

Conjugation

Transformation

Transduction

Mechanism

Direct cell to cell transfer from the donor bacterium to the recipient bacterium.

Uptake of extracellular naked DNA from the environment by a competent recipient bacterium.

Transmission of genetic material from the donor bacterium to the recipient bacterium through a bacteriophage.

Requirements

Conjugation tube or pilus

Naked DNA and competent cell

Bacteriophage virus

questions.text: The Holder pasteurisation method is widely used for preserving milk and other dairy products. In this method, the milk is heated at a specific temperature for a specific time to kill the pathogenic microorganisms present in it. Which of the following statements is true regarding the Holder method of pasteurisation?

options.label: A
options.text: The temperature and time of heating required for pasteurisation depend on the type of microorganisms present in the milk.

options.label: B
options.text: The Holder method of pasteurisation is ineffective against all types of microorganisms in the milk.

options.label: C
options.text: The Holder method of pasteurisation is a type of sterilisation method that kills all microorganisms in the milk.

options.label: D
options.text: The temperature and time of heating required for pasteurisation are determined by the type of dairy product being pasteurised.

questions.correct_answer: B. The Holder method of pasteurisation is ineffective against all types of microorganisms in the milk.
questions.explanation:
Holder method

63o C for 30 minutes

Flash method

72o C for 20 seconds then followed by cooling quickly to 13o C and lower than that.

questions.text: A microbiology laboratory is testing the effectiveness of three different disinfectants against a strain of Pseudomonas aeruginosa. The disinfectants are A, B, and C. The table below shows the results of the experiment. Disinfectant Concentration Contact time (min) Log reduction (CFU/mL) A 1:100 10 1.5 A 1:50 10 2.5 A 1:25 10 3.5 B 1:100 5 1.0 B 1:50 5 2.0 B 1:25 5 3.0 C 1:100 30 2.5 C 1:50 30 3.5 C 1:25 30 4.5 Which of the following disinfectants would be most effective against Pseudomonas aeruginosa in a healthcare setting?

options.label: A
options.text: Disinfectant A at 1:25 concentration for 5 min contact time

options.label: B
options.text: Disinfectant B at 1:50 concentration for 10 min contact time

options.label: C
options.text: Disinfectant C at 1:100 concentration for 5 min contact time

options.label: D
options.text: Disinfectant C at 1:25 concentration for 10 min contact time

questions.correct_answer: D. Disinfectant C at 1:25 concentration for 10 min contact time

questions.text: A 56-year-old male presents to the emergency department with fever, chills, and shortness of breath. His physical examination is significant for a temperature of 38.5°C, respiratory rate of 24 breaths/minute, and oxygen saturation of 90% on room air. A chest x-ray reveals bilateral pulmonary infiltrates and a sputum culture grows Klebsiella pneumoniae. Laboratory studies show a white blood cell count of 18,000/mm3, with 85% neutrophils, a C-reactive protein (CRP) level of 150 mg/L, and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) of 85 mm/hour. Based on these findings, which acute phase reactants are most likely to be elevated in this patient?

A 25-year-old female presents with a high fever, vomiting, and a diffuse macular rash. She reports using a tampon for several days during her menstrual period. Blood cultures revealed the presence of Staphylococcus aureus. Which of the following toxins is most likely responsible for her clinical presentation?

A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department with symptoms of shortness of breath, swelling of the face and lips, and hives all over his body. He reports that he recently started taking a new medication for his rheumatoid arthritis. Physical examination reveals tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypotension. The patient's medication is immediately stopped and treated with intravenous fluids, antihistamines, and corticosteroids. Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is the patient most likely experiencing?
questions.explanation:
Characteristics

Types of Hypersensitivities

Type I

(Anaphylactic)

Type II

(Cytotoxic)

Type III

(Immune complex)

Type IV

(Delayed or cell mediated)

Mechanism of Activation

Allergen-specific IgE antibodies bind to mast cells, and when allergen binds to the antibodies, cross-link induces degranulation of mast cells.

IgM or IgG antibodies bind to the antigen, leading to complement activation and cell lysis.

Antigen-antibody complexes are deposited in tissues; complement activation provides inflammatory mediators and recruits neutrophils; neutrophils release enzymes that damage tissues.

TH1 cells secrete cytokinins that activate macrophages and cytotoxic T-cells.

Immune Reactant

IgE

IgG or IgM

IgG and IgM

T cells

Antigenic Form

Soluble

Cell-bound

Soluble

Soluble or Cell-bound

questions.text: A laboratory technician performed a bipolar gram staining procedure on a clinical sample obtained from a patient with suspected meningitis. After applying crystal violet, iodine, and alcohol, the technician observed that the bacteria in the sample appeared red-pink under the microscope. Which of the following statements best explains this observation?

options.label: A
options.text: The bacteria are gram-negative and have a thick peptidoglycan layer

options.label: B
options.text: The bacteria are gram-positive and have a thin peptidoglycan layer

options.label: C
options.text: The bacteria are gram-negative and have a thin peptidoglycan layer

options.label: D
options.text: The bacteria are gram-positive and have a thick peptidoglycan layer

questions.correct_answer: C. The bacteria are gram-negative and have a thin peptidoglycan layer

questions.text: A 45-year-old diabetic patient presents to the hospital with a 2-week history of fever, headache, and blurred vision. On examination, he is found to have left-sided facial swelling and proptosis. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated blood sugar levels, leukocytosis, and thrombocytopenia. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the head and sinuses shows opacification of the left maxillary and ethmoid sinuses and a left-sided orbital apex lesion. A lesion biopsy reveals the presence of broad, aseptate hyphae with right-angle branching. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?

A 32-year-old female presents with a painless, mobile, well-defined lump in her left breast. The lump is around 2 cm in size and has been increasing in size over the past few months. Ultrasound-guided biopsy of the lump revealed a fibroadenoma. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

A 50-year-old female presents with a palpable breast lump. A core biopsy is performed, and the pathology report confirms invasive ductal carcinoma. The patient undergoes a lumpectomy with sentinel lymph node biopsy, and the final pathology report shows a 2.5 cm tumour with no lymph node involvement. Based on the TNM staging system, what is this patient’s breast cancer stage?

A 35-year-old female presents with a history of weight gain, central obesity, moon face, and purple striae on her abdomen. Her blood pressure is elevated, and she has easy bruising. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated cortisol levels, and an MRI shows a pituitary adenoma. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

A 40-year-old patient presents with hypertension, headache, palpitations, and diaphoresis. Further evaluation reveals an adrenal mass and laboratory tests demonstrate elevated levels of metanephrines and catecholamines. What is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Surgical resection of the adrenal mass

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with a dry cough, shortness of breath, and fever. Imaging reveals bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and interstitial lung disease. Further investigation reveals non-caseating granulomas. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?

A 3-month-old infant presents to the clinic with a large, painless mass on the left side of the neck. Upon examination, the mass is found to be a cystic hygroma. The parents are concerned about the potential complications and ask about the management options. Consider the following statements. Surgery is the first-line treatment for cystic hygroma. Sclerotherapy is a potential treatment option for cystic hygroma. Radiotherapy is a potential treatment option for cystic hygroma. Aspiration of the cystic hygroma is the preferred initial management strategy. Cystic hygromas are always benign and do not require any treatment. Cystic hygromas are commonly associated with chromosomal abnormalities such as Turner syndrome. Which of the following statements is/are true regarding managing cystic hygroma?

A 42-year-old male patient with a history of parotidectomy was brought to a clinic with symptoms like redness around the cheek area accompanied by sweating and itching. Later he was diagnosed with Dupuy's syndrome. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this condition?

A 28-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department following a physical altercation. The patient complains of severe pain and swelling around the midface region. Upon examination, the patient is found to have a complex facial fracture that involves the Le Forte II fracture and an orbital floor fracture. Which of the following is a potential complication associated with this type of complex facial fracture?

A 45-year-old male patient presents with trismus and progressive difficulty in opening his mouth. He has a long-standing history of tobacco and betel nut chewing. On examination, he has a fibrotic band in the buccal mucosa and limited mouth opening. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Surgical excision of the fibrotic band

options.label: C
options.text: Betel nut cessation and supportive care

options.label: D
options.text: Combination therapy with pentoxifylline and tocopherol

questions.correct_answer: B. Surgical excision of the fibrotic band

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the surgical clinic complaining of leg pain, heaviness, and swelling. On examination, the patient has visibly enlarged veins in her legs, with the largest one measuring approximately 5mm in diameter. The patient also reports experiencing worsening symptoms when standing or sitting for long periods of time. An ultrasound is performed, which reveals reflux in the saphenofemoral junction and incompetent perforator veins. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's presentation, and what surgical management options should be considered?

options.label: B
options.text: Peripheral arterial disease; angioplasty and stenting

options.label: C
options.text: Varicose veins; endovenous laser treatment and sclerotherapy

options.label: D
options.text: Chronic venous insufficiency; saphenous vein stripping and radiofrequency ablation

questions.correct_answer: C. Varicose veins; endovenous laser treatment and sclerotherapy

questions.text: A 50-year-old male complains of facial swelling, cough, and dyspnea. On examination, he has dilated veins over the neck and upper chest. Imaging studies revealed a mediastinal mass compressing the superior vena cava (SVC). Which of the following is NOT a common cause of SVC syndrome?

A 45-year-old male with a history of Crohn's disease presents to the hospital with severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. CT scan of the abdomen shows dilation of the small bowel with proximal bowel loops measuring up to 5 cm in diameter. The patient undergoes surgical intervention, and intraoperatively, a long segment of thickened, inflamed small bowel is identified with areas of fibrosis and stenosis. A biopsy of the bowel reveals transmural inflammation with granulomas. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the recommended surgical management?

A 28-year-old female presents with episodes of pain, numbness, and discoloration of her fingers and toes upon exposure to cold temperatures or stress. She reports that her symptoms improve when she warms her extremities. She has a history of migraines and is a smoker. On examination, her fingers appear cyanotic and have reduced capillary refill time. Her nails are thickened and curved, and she has digital ulcers. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 42-year-old male presented to the hospital with complaints of severe pain in the hands and feet. On inspection, it was observed that the fingers and toes of hands and feet appeared bluish. He was diagnosed with thromboangitis obliterans. Which of the following can be considered as a treatment for the 42-year-old male diagnosed with thromboangitis obliterans?

A 47-year-old male presents with shortness of breath and palpitations. Echocardiography reveals a large, mobile mass in the left atrium. Surgical removal of the mass is planned. Which of the following is the most appropriate approach for surgical excision of the left atrial myxoma?
questions.correct_answer: C. Left atrial free wall excision

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presented with abdominal pain and vomiting. On physical examination, the patient was found to have a palpable mass in the epigastric region. Computed tomography (CT) scan revealed a Bochdalek hernia with the stomach and spleen herniated into the chest cavity. Which of the following is the most appropriate management strategy for this 45-year-old female?

options.label: A
options.text: Conservative management with observation and follow-up imaging

options.label: B
options.text: Laparoscopic reduction and repair of the hernia

options.label: C
options.text: Open surgical repair of the hernia

options.label: D
options.text: Non-surgical management with proton pump inhibitors and H2 blockers

questions.correct_answer: C. Open surgical repair of the hernia

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with a long-standing history of heartburn and acid regurgitation, which has been interfering with his daily activities. He has been taking proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) regularly for the past 2 years but has not experienced any significant relief of his symptoms. On upper gastrointestinal endoscopy, he is diagnosed with GERD. What is the most effective surgical option for the treatment of this patient's GERD?
questions.explanation:
Types of fundoplication 

 

  1. Watson fundoplication 

 

  • Fundus of stomach is taken to cover only 900 /one fourth of oesophagus anteriorly 

 

 

  1. DOR fundoplication

 

  • Fundus of stomach is taken to cover 1800 of esophagus anteriorly 

 

  1. Toupet fundoplication 

 

  • Fundus of stomach is taken to 2700 of esophagus posteriorly 

 

 

  1. Belsey Mark IV

 

  • Fundus of stomach is taken to cover 2700 of esophagus anteriorly 
  

 

  1. Nissen’s fundoplication for 3600

 

  • M/c performed
  • One part of fundus is taken behind the esophagus of other part of fundus is taken in front of eshophagus
  • Both of them are plicated in front of eshophagus 

 

 

  • MC performed fundoplication – Nissen’s fundoplication 
  • Rarely performed fundoplication 

 

  • Watson fundoplication
  • Belsey Mark IV fundoplication 

 

  • MC performed Partial fundoplication 

 

  • DOR fundoplication 
  • Toupet fundoplication

questions.text: A 4-week-old male infant presents to the emergency department with a 2-week history of persistent vomiting, irritability, and poor weight gain. The mother reports that the vomitus is non-bilious, projectile, and forceful. On examination, the infant appears dehydrated and malnourished. The abdomen is soft but shows a palpable, elongated mass in the epigastric region. The infant is diagnosed with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (HPS). Which of the following diagnostic modalities is considered the gold standard for the diagnosis of HPS, and what is the appropriate management for this condition?

A 36-year-old man is presented to the emergency department with sudden onset vomiting of bright red blood after a large meal. He reports feeling nauseous and retching several times before the onset of hematemesis. The patient is hemodynamically stable and has no other significant medical history. On examination, there is no abdominal tenderness, and laboratory tests are within normal limits. What is the most likely diagnosis for this 36-year-old man's presentation?

A 65-year-old male patient has been brought to the emergency department with abdominal pain, distention, and constipation for the last 2 days. The patient has a history of chronic constipation and has not had a bowel movement for the last 48 hours. The physical examination reveals tenderness in the lower abdomen, hyperactive bowel sounds, and a tympanic abdomen. An abdominal X-ray shows a dilated sigmoid colon with air-fluid levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old male presents with complaints of difficulty swallowing solid food for the last few months. He also reports occasional regurgitation of undigested food, chest pain, and weight loss. He had a history of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) for the last 5 years, which was managed with medications. A barium swallow study reveals a dilated esophagus with a narrowed lower esophageal sphincter (LES). Esophageal manometry shows incomplete relaxation of the LES and increased lower esophageal sphincter pressure. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with sudden chest pain and shortness of breath. His blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, his heart rate is 120 beats per minute, and he has no palpable pulse. The cardiac monitor shows organized electrical activity, but there are no mechanical contractions of the heart. Which of the following is the most likely cause?

A 32-year-old woman with a history of type 1 diabetes presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and altered mental status. The patient's blood glucose level is 450 mg/dL, serum bicarbonate is 10 mEq/L, and serum ketones are elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old man presents to the endocrine clinic with a history of recurrent episodes of peptic ulcer disease, parathyroid hyperplasia, and pituitary adenoma. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 34-year-old female presents to the emergency department with fatigue, weight loss, and low blood pressure symptoms. She reports that her symptoms have progressively worsened over the past few months. Lab tests reveal low levels of cortisol and high levels of ACTH. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

A 45-year-old female presents with complaints of neck swelling and difficulty in swallowing for the past few months. Upon examination, a palpable lump is noted in the anterior neck region. A thyroid function test is within normal limits, but an elevated calcitonin level is noted. An ultrasound-guided lump biopsy is performed, revealing medullary thyroid cancer. What will be the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Total thyroidectomy with central compartment neck dissection

options.label: C
options.text: Observation with serial calcitonin level monitoring

options.label: D
options.text: Surgery followed by radiotherapy to the neck region

questions.correct_answer: A. Total thyroidectomy with central compartment neck dissection

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents to the clinic complaining of hypertension and muscle weakness. Physical examination reveals no abnormal findings. Laboratory investigations show elevated serum aldosterone levels and low renin levels. Which of the subsequent diagnoses is most likely?

A 35-year-old female patient presents to the clinic with a tender and enlarged thyroid gland, accompanied by pain in the neck and difficulty swallowing. The patient reports a recent viral illness. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated levels of thyroid hormones and low thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 38-year-old female presents to the endocrinology clinic with complaints of fatigue, weight gain, constipation, and dry skin. On physical examination, she has a diffuse goiter and mild tenderness over the thyroid gland. Laboratory tests reveal elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels and low free thyroxine (T4) levels. Anti-thyroid peroxidase (anti-TPO) antibodies are positive. A thyroid ultrasound shows diffuse hypoechogenicity and increased vascularity. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 60-year-old man presents to the emergency department with left lower abdominal pain that has increased in severity over the past 2 days. He reports having had several episodes of constipation and diarrhea over the past few weeks. On physical exam, there is tenderness and guarding in the left lower quadrant of the abdomen. A CT scan is ordered, which shows colonic diverticula and thickening of the sigmoid colon consistent with diverticulitis. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Intravenous antibiotics and admission to the hospital

questions.correct_answer: B. Intravenous antibiotics and admission to the hospital

questions.text: Passaro's triangle lies between the splenic vein, cystic duct, and which of the following anatomical structures?

A 62-year-old male presents with severe bone pain and fatigue that has persisted for the last few weeks. On examination, he has tenderness along the spine. Blood investigations reveal anemia and high levels of serum calcium. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient based on the clinical scenario?
Which of the following heart sounds is associated with the filling of the ventricles during diastole?

A 65-year-old man presents with a 6-month history of shortness of breath and palpitations. On examination, a grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur is heard best at the second right intercostal space. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 62-year-old male with a history of rheumatic heart disease presents with fever, chills, and fatigue for the past week. On physical examination, a new holosystolic murmur is heard at the apex. Blood cultures are positive for Streptococcus viridans. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 40-year-old man admitted to the emergency department with shortness of breath and confusion. Arterial blood gas analysis shows a pH of 7.25, pCO2 of 40 mmHg, HCO3- of 16 mEq/L, and anion gap of 18. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: B
options.text: Metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap

options.label: C
options.text: Metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap

questions.correct_answer: B. Metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe pain in his right flank that radiates to his groin. He has a past medical history of recurrent urinary tract infections. Imaging studies reveal a 3.75 cm stone in the right distal ureter. Which one of the following represents the most appropriate initial management?

A 55-year-old male patient presents with abdominal pain, yellowing of the skin and eyes, decreased appetite, and fatigue. Imaging reveals liver cirrhosis. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his cirrhosis?

A 32-year-old has complained of abdominal pain, distension, and yellowish discoloration of the skin and eyes for the past week. She has a past medical history of autoimmune hepatitis and was on treatment with azathioprine and prednisolone. On examination, she has hepatomegaly, ascites, and spider angiomata. Laboratory tests reveal elevated liver enzymes, hyperbilirubinemia, and decreased serum albumin. Imaging studies show hepatic vein occlusion with dilated hepatic veins and collateral formation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 65-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking. On further evaluation, he is diagnosed with a stroke. Which of the following is this patient's most common cause of ischemic stroke?

A 7-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her parents, who report that she has been experiencing brief episodes of staring and unresponsiveness for the past several months. The episodes typically last 10-15 seconds and occur multiple times daily. During the episodes, the child does not respond to verbal or physical stimuli and may exhibit slight eye fluttering. After the episode, the child resumes normal activities without confusion or lethargy. Her neurological examination is normal. An electroencephalogram (EEG) shows 3 Hz generalized spike-and-wave discharges. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

A 20-year-old female presents with chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and infertility. She has a history of recurrent respiratory tract infections since childhood. On examination, she has situs inversus, and chest X-ray shows dextrocardia. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25-year-old female presents with complaints of irregular menstrual cycles for the past 6 months. On examination, her uterus is of normal size, and there are no other significant findings. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her irregular menstrual cycles?

A 55-year-old postmenopausal female presents with symptoms of hot flashes, night sweats, and vaginal dryness. She has no history of breast cancer, blood clots, or cardiovascular disease. Which of the following is the most appropriate hormone replacement therapy (HRT) option for this patient?

A 32-year-old female presents to the clinic with a request for long-acting contraception. She has two children and is not planning to have any more children soon. She has tried birth control pills in the past but had difficulty remembering to take them consistently. On examination, she has no contraindications to intrauterine devices (IUDs) or contraceptive implants. Which of the following is the most appropriate contraceptive option for this patient?

A 28-year-old nulliparous woman presents with severe dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, and chronic pelvic pain. The physical examination is unremarkable, and an ultrasound shows a 3 cm endometrioma on the left ovary. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Prescribe NSAIDs and reassess in 3 months

options.label: B
options.text: Initiate hormonal therapy with a combined oral contraceptive pill

options.label: C
options.text: Perform laparoscopic excision of the endometrioma

options.label: D
options.text: Refer for in vitro fertilization (IVF) to achieve pregnancy

questions.correct_answer: C. Perform laparoscopic excision of the endometrioma

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with a pelvic mass discovered incidentally during a routine gynecologic examination. Ultrasound shows a multiloculated cystic mass measuring 10 cm in diameter, and MRI confirms the presence of a cystic mass with internal septations. Laboratory studies show elevated levels of CA 125. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's pelvic mass?

A 16-year-old girl presents to the clinic with concerns about acne and weight gain. She reports having irregular periods but denies excess facial hair or other symptoms. On examination, she has a BMI of 25 and mild acne. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of androgens. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's clinical presentation?

A 26-year-old woman presents to the gynecology clinic for a routine Pap smear. Her Pap smear is positive for high-risk human papillomavirus (HPV) types. She reports no symptoms and has no significant past medical history. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

A 45-year-old female presents with vaginal and post-coital bleeding for the last two months. She has a history of irregular menstrual periods; her history of sexual partners wasn't disclosed. On pelvic examination, cervical growth is noted. A biopsy of the lesion confirms squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix. Which of the following statements about cervical cancer is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Most common site for cancer cervix is Squamo columnar junction.

options.label: B
options.text: Most common site for cancer cervix is Transformation Zone.

options.label: C
options.text: Cervical cancer screening should be started at age 40 in women with no risk factors.

options.label: D
options.text: The most common histological type of cervical cancer is adenocarcinoma.

questions.correct_answer: B. Most common site for cancer cervix is Transformation Zone.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic pain. She reports having regular menstrual cycles and no significant past medical history. Pelvic examination reveals an enlarged uterus. Transvaginal ultrasound shows multiple uterine fibroids. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A 45-year-old female presents with complaints of urine leakage from her vagina for the past 6 months. She reports a history of a complicated vaginal delivery 15 years ago, with a prolonged second stage of labor and the use of forceps. On physical examination, there is evidence of urine in the vaginal vault, and a urine dipstick test is positive for the presence of leukocytes and nitrites. Which of the following diagnosis is most likely appropriate for this patient's symptoms?

A 28-year-old sexually active female with a history of taking OCPs comes to the clinic with complaints of vaginal pruritis and thick curd-like vaginal discharge. On per vaginal examination, there were creamy white plaques. Which of the following STD treatment kits should be used for the management of the patient?

A 32-year-old woman presents to the clinic complaining of amenorrhea and difficulty breastfeeding. She had a postpartum haemorrhage during delivery and required blood transfusions. On examination, she was found to have low blood pressure and a pale complexion. Laboratory tests reveal low levels of all anterior pituitary hormones. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's clinical presentation?

A 32-year-old woman presents with infertility. She has regular menstrual cycles and no significant past medical history. Pelvic examination and transvaginal ultrasound are normal. Hysterosalpingogram (HSG) reveals a unicornuate uterus with a single patent fallopian tube. Which of the following accounts for this finding the most likely?

options.label: B
options.text: Congenital absence of one fallopian tube

options.label: D
options.text: Pelvic adhesions leading to tubal occlusion

questions.text: Which structures provide the primary support for the uterus?

A pregnant woman presents with vaginal bleeding at 12 weeks gestation. On pelvic examination, she has a bluish-purple discoloration of the cervix. What is the most likely explanation for this finding?

A 30-year-old woman with a history of pelvic inflammatory disease presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. She is hemodynamically stable. Her serum beta-hCG is positive, and transvaginal ultrasound shows a 2-cm adnexal mass. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old pregnant woman presents for genetic counseling. Her non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) reveals an increased risk for trisomy 21. A diagnostic test is recommended, and chorionic villus sampling (CVS) is performed at 13 weeks of gestation. The CVS results are normal. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the discrepancy between the NIPT and CVS results?

A 34-year-old female presents at 32 weeks of gestation with sudden onset of painless vaginal bleeding. The fetal heart rate is normal on examination, and there is no evidence of uterine contractions. Which of the subsequent diagnoses is most likely?

A 30-year-old pregnant woman presents for routine prenatal care at 28 weeks gestation. Ultrasound reveals fetal hydrops with pericardial and pleural effusions, ascites, and skin edema. Which of the following is the most likely cause of fetal hydrops in this case?

A 26-year-old primigravida at 35 weeks gestation presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe headache, visual changes, and abdominal pain. She has a history of gestational hypertension that has been managed with bed rest and close monitoring. Her blood pressure on admission is 160/100 mmHg, and her urine dipstick is positive for protein. Her laboratory results are significant for thrombocytopenia and elevated liver enzymes. She eventually has a seizure in the emergency department. Which of the following initial management seems most appropriate for this patient?

A 5-year-old child presented with a fever, cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis followed by a maculopapular rash, starting from the face and then spreading to the trunk and extremities. The rash lasted for about 5-6 days, and the child recovered completely. Which of the following is true regarding the diagnosis of this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: A throat swab is necessary for the diagnosis of this condition

options.label: B
options.text: IgM antibody testing is the gold standard for the diagnosis of this condition

options.label: C
options.text: A positive serology is required for the diagnosis of this condition

options.label: D
options.text: Clinical features and a history of contact with a confirmed case are sufficient for the diagnosis of this condition.

questions.correct_answer: D. Clinical features and a history of contact with a confirmed case are sufficient for the diagnosis of this condition.

questions.text: A rural PHC senior doctor asked his interns to prepare various charts and diagrams in order to guide and create awareness among the villagers. Identify the Logo shown in the Photograph below?

A 7-year-old boy from a rural area was brought to a primary health center for a routine health check-up. The healthcare worker who examined the child noticed that he was not able to hear properly and also had a visible cleft palate. The healthcare worker informed the child's parents about the Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) and advised them to take the child for screening under the program. Which of the following statements is true regarding RBSK in this case?

options.label: A
options.text: RBSK is a program initiated by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare to provide comprehensive healthcare services to children under the age of 5 years

options.label: B
options.text: RBSK provides screening for 30 health conditions, including physical, cognitive, sensory, and social disabilities

options.label: C
options.text: RBSK services are available only in private hospitals and clinics.

options.label: D
options.text: RBSK is not applicable to children living in rural areas

questions.correct_answer: B. RBSK provides screening for 30 health conditions, including physical, cognitive, sensory, and social disabilities

questions.text: DALYs is Disability adjusted life years and it is the best indicator of ‘’disease Burden''. What is the MCC of DALYs lost among Mental health disorders?

A 34-year-old woman presented to the clinic with symptoms of fever, malaise, and cough for two weeks. She has a history of unprotected sexual intercourse with multiple partners. On examination, she had enlarged cervical lymph nodes and a diffuse maculopapular rash. Her CD4 cell count was 200 cells/mm3. A chest X-ray showed diffuse infiltrates. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?

A hospital in a rural area is struggling with the proper management of biomedical waste. The hospital staff has been observed disposing of all the biomedical waste in a single bin without any segregation. This is causing concern for the hospital administration as well as the community. Upon investigation, it was found that there was no proper training provided to the staff regarding biomedical waste management. The hospital administration decides to take corrective measures and provide training to the staff on the proper segregation of biomedical waste. During the training, which of the following statements regarding the segregation of biomedical waste would be most appropriate for the hospital administration to convey to the staff?

options.label: A
options.text: All types of biomedical waste should be placed in the same bin for disposal

options.label: B
options.text: Infectious waste should be segregated from non-infectious waste

options.label: C
options.text: Sharps waste should be disposed of in ordinary waste bins

options.label: D
options.text: Chemical waste should be segregated from pharmaceutical waste

questions.correct_answer: B. Infectious waste should be segregated from non-infectious waste

questions.text: A public health center receives a new shipment of vaccines and drugs for its immunization program. The center's medical officer in charge instructs the staff to store the vaccines and drugs appropriately. A few days later, the officer received a complaint from a community member that their child developed a fever after receiving a vaccine from the center. Upon investigation, it was found that the vaccines were stored in a storage room with no temperature monitoring system. The room had a temperature of 20°C, much higher than the recommended storage temperature range of 2-8°C. What is the most likely cause of the child's fever?

options.label: A
options.text: Bacterial contamination of the vaccine during manufacturing

options.label: B
options.text: Incorrect administration of the vaccine by the center's staff

options.label: C
options.text: The vaccine's potency was affected due to incorrect storage temperature

options.label: D
options.text: The child was allergic to one of the vaccine's components.

questions.correct_answer: C. The vaccine's potency was affected due to incorrect storage temperature

questions.text: A study was conducted to assess the effectiveness of a new intervention in reducing the incidence of hypertension in a population. The study produced conflicting results, with some studies reporting a significant reduction in hypertension while others reported no significant effect. Which of the following study designs would be most appropriate to combine the results of the studies and provide a summary estimate of the effect size of the intervention?

A public health researcher conducted a randomized controlled trial to test the effectiveness of a new smoking cessation program in reducing the number of cigarettes smoked per day. The trial included three groups: a control group that received no intervention, a group that received a brief counselling session, and a group that received the full smoking cessation program. The researcher collected data on the number of cigarettes smoked per day at baseline and after 6 months of follow-up. The data were analysed using ANOVA. What is the appropriate use of ANOVA in this study?

options.label: A
options.text: Comparing the proportion of smokers in each group

options.label: B
options.text: Assessing the prevalence of smoking among individuals with different demographic characteristics

options.label: C
options.text: Comparing the mean number of cigarettes smoked per day among individuals in each group

options.label: D
options.text: Assessing the impact of the intervention on quit rates among smokers

questions.correct_answer: C. Comparing the mean number of cigarettes smoked per day among individuals in each group
questions.explanation:
TEST INFORMATION

Parametric test
  • ANOVA
  • Pearson correlation
  • Student’s T- Test

Non-parametric test
  • Chi-square test
  • Wilcoxon rank sum test
  • Fisher’s exact probability test

Chi-square test
  • It uses to determine the difference between 2 or more percentages or proportions of the categorical outcome.
ANOVA test
  • It uses to determine the difference between the means of 3 or more groups

Student’s T-test
  • It uses to determine the difference between the mean of 2 groups.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male is brought to the emergency department with a head injury after being involved in a car accident. The patient opens his eye and flexion of limb occurs on pinch. He is speaking in appropriate words. what is his GCS score?

questions.text: Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is a crucial indicator of the effectiveness of a country's healthcare system. It reflects the quality of obstetric care and the accessibility of health services for pregnant women. The World Health Organization defines MMR as the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births. The MMR is affected by various factors such as socioeconomic status, education, and healthcare infrastructure. In a country, the MMR was 450 deaths per 100,000 live births in the year 2015. In the year 2020, the MMR reduced to 300 deaths per 100,000 live births. Calculate the percentage reduction in MMR during this period.

A 28-year-old pregnant woman from a rural area in India presents to the antenatal clinic for her first check-up. During the routine investigations, she is found to have anemia. On further inquiry, the patient reveals that her diet is mainly vegetarian and lacks diversity. She also reports heavy menstrual bleeding. The healthcare worker advises her to start taking iron and folic acid tablets and counsels her on the importance of a balanced diet. Which component of the Anemia Mukt Bharat Programme is being implemented in this scenario?

options.label: A
options.text: Weekly Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) supplementation for adolescent girls and pregnant women.

options.label: B
options.text: Introduction of fortified food products in the public distribution system.

options.label: C
options.text: Promotion of dietary diversity and nutrition education.

options.label: D
options.text: Universal salt iodization to prevent hypothyroidism.

questions.correct_answer: A. Weekly Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) supplementation for adolescent girls and pregnant women.

questions.text: A 15 year old male presented to the OPD with complains of high fever, headache, tremors and stiff neck 10 days after returning from his trip to Australia. He recalls of having lots of mosquito bites during his travel. The blood reports confirmed Japanese encephalitis as the diagnosis. Which of the following is the Amplifier host in Japanese encephalitis?
In a community, the range of systolic blood pressure readings among adults is between 90-190 mmHg. Which of the following is the most appropriate measure of central tendency to represent this data?

In a rural village in a developing country, a sudden outbreak of diarrhoea has affected many residents; however, none of the cases reported bloody diarrhoea. After investigating, the public health officials found that the outbreak’s source was contaminated drinking water. The water source was a nearby well, which had become contaminated with faecal matter due to poor sanitation practices in the village. The officials immediately took action to provide clean water to the affected population and educated them on the importance of proper sanitation and hygiene practices. Upon inspection of the contaminated water source, it was observed that the causative agent was a bacterium. Which of the following waterborne diseases could have caused the village’s diarrhoea outbreak?

In a study on the performance of a new diagnostic test for tuberculosis, 200 patients were enrolled. The reference standard was the presence of clinical symptoms and sputum culture positivity for Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The test result was positive in 50 patients and negative in 150 patients. There were 40 true positive and 15 false negative cases. Calculate the sensitivity and specificity of the new diagnostic test.
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Understanding of the concepts of Sensitivity and Specificity and their importance in diagnostic testing.
  • ↳ Ability to calculate Sensitivity and Specificity from given data.
  • ↳ Knowledge of factors that can affect the performance of diagnostic tests, including the prevalence of the disease, the reference standard used, and the cutoff value for test results.
  • ↳ Knowledge of the clinical implications of Sensitivity and Specificity, including their impact on the accuracy of test results and the likelihood of false positives and false negatives.
  • ↳ Understanding of the role of Sensitivity and Specificity in public health interventions, including disease screening and surveillance programs.
  • ↳ Ability to interpret and communicate Sensitivity and Specificity results to healthcare professionals, policymakers, and the general public.
  • ↳ Overall, understanding Sensitivity and Specificity is essential in PSM as it helps in assessing the effectiveness of diagnostic tests and informs clinical decision-making and public health interventions.
